captions.text:
- Right now, a private company
called Myriad Genetics
owns a piece of your body.
That's a really bad idea.
It patented two genes:
breast cancer 1 and 2,
or BRCA 1 and 2.

Certain mutations
on these genes give women
a strong chance of getting
breast or ovarian cancer.

The problem is,
Myriad Genetics says
because of the patents,

it's the only one allowed
to test these genes.
That's more than a bad idea.

The law says no one can get
a patent on products of nature
or laws of nature,

but Myriad says once it removes
the genes from your body,
it owns them.
That's not how the law works.

For example,
you can't patent a mineral.
Take iron.
It's found in rock.

To use iron, you have
to remove it from the rock.

Now, you can patent
the process
of removing iron from rock,

and you can patent the things
you make from that iron,

but you cannot patent
the iron itself,

even after you take it
out of the rock,
because it's still iron.

That makes sense,
right?

Well, the same laws apply
when it comes to your genes.

Right now, only Myriad Genetics
is allowed

to test for mutations
on BRCA 1 and 2.

You have to pay them
big bucks for the test
because there's no competition.

And in most cases, you can't get
a second test elsewhere,

which you'd probably want
if you were thinking

about removing your breasts
or ovaries.

And no scientist
outside of Myriad
can work on these genes

to offer better tests
to patients
or help find a cure.
Are you getting the picture?
It's a really bad idea.

The U.S. Supreme Court
is about to decide

whether a private company
like Myriad
can own a piece of us.

Let's tell the world
what we think.

True, a company can't hold a patent forever or research would be stifled

yield any profit. This particular case is interesting since the research 
cannot be sold as a drug. Regardless, the biggest incentive behind research 
is money. Take that away and there wont be any innovation

comments.text:
I agree with you hendem, but think about the residual outcome of them 
owning a defective gene of yours. Let's take Henrietta Lack for instance - 
her genes were and still are used in Cancer research. Although obtained 
illegally and unethically, they provide scientists all over the world with 
an endless supply of test material. That's the thing though, it's available 
to scientists all over the world. What they're proposing here is owning 
exclusive, unashamed rights to your extracted genome.

comments.author: mikecorbeil

comments.text:
How can a company patent human, animal, plant, ... genetics unless the 
company created these genetics? If it created them and implanted these in 
humans, then it's clearly without the victims being aware of what was going 
on. So, the company would be guilty of criminal negligence, at the very 
best or least that the company could get away with in a real court of law. 
If I was a jurist, then I'd vote for far stronger than criminal negligence 
and the corporate chiefs would have many prison years.
comments.author: mikecorbeil

comments.text:

fullest extent and it's that no one can own you or have copyright on you in 
any way whatsoever.
comments.author: mikecorbeil
